content.question: The diagram above shows the distribution of speeds for a sample of <math alttext="N 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following graphs shows the distribution of speeds for a sample of <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (dashed line) ?

choices.label: The figure presents the graph of two curves. The horizontal axis is labeled Speed, and the vertical axis is labeled Relative Number of Molecules. The first curve is a bolded line that begins where the axes meet, and moves gradually upward and to the right initially. It then moves steeply upward and to the right, and reaches its maximum roughly one third of the way along the horizontal axis and two thirds of the way up the vertical axis. It then moves gradually downward and to the right, and begins to level off as it approaches the x axis, ending at a point about one fourth of the way up the vertical axis, above the end of the horizontal axis. The second curve is a dashed line that begins where axes meet, and moves more steeply upward and to the right than the first curve. It reaches its maximum above and to the left of where the first curve reaches its maximum, and then moves downward and to the right until it ends at the end of the horizontal axis.

The figure presents the graph of two curves. The horizontal axis is labeled Speed, and the vertical axis is labeled Relative Number of Molecules. The first curve is a bolded line that begins where the axes meet, and moves gradually upward and to the right initially. It then moves steeply upward and to the right, and reaches its maximum roughly one third of the way along the horizontal axis and two thirds of the way up the vertical axis. It then moves gradually downward and to the right, and begins to level off as it approaches the x axis, ending at a point about one fourth of the way up the vertical axis, above the end of the horizontal axis. The second curve is a dashed line that begins where the axes meet, and moves steeply upward and to the right. It reaches its maximum, below and to the left of where the first curve reaches its maximum, and then moves very gradually downward and to the right until it ends just above the first curve.

The figure presents the graph of two curves. The horizontal axis is labeled Speed, and the vertical axis is labeled Relative Number of Molecules. The first curve is a bolded line that begins where the axes meet, and moves gradually upward and to the right initially. It then moves steeply upward and to the right, and reaches its maximum roughly one third of the way along the horizontal axis and two thirds of the way up the vertical axis. It then moves gradually downward and to the right, and begins to level off as it approaches the x axis, ending at a point about one fourth of the way up the vertical axis, above the end of the horizontal axis. The second curve is a dashed line that begins where the axes meet, and moves more gradually upward and to the right than the first curve. It reaches its maximum, below and to the right of where the first curve reaches its maximum, and then moves downward and to the right until it ends above the first curve.

The figure presents the graph of two curves. The horizontal axis is labeled Speed, and the vertical axis is labeled Relative Number of Molecules. The first curve is a bolded line that begins where the axes meet, and moves gradually upward and to the right initially. It then moves steeply upward and to the right, and reaches its maximum roughly one third of the way along the horizontal axis and two thirds of the way up the vertical axis. It then moves gradually downward and to the right, and begins to level off as it approaches the x axis, ending at a point about one fourth of the way up the vertical axis, above the end of the horizontal axis. The second curve is a dashed line that begins directly to the right of the first curve, and moves upward and to the right at the same rate as the first curve. It reaches its maximum directly to the right of where the first curve reaches its maximum, and then moves gradually downward and to the right where it ends slightly above the first curve.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
